{{notability|organizations|date=June 2017}}
'''US Nuclear Corporation''' is a US [[Radioactivity|radiation detection]] [[holding company]] headquartered in [[Canoga Park, CA]]<ref>http://new.usnuclearcorp.com/contact-us/</ref> specializing in the development and manufacturing of radiation detection instrumentation. It supplies instrumentation to [[nuclear power plant]]s, national laboratories, government agencies, [[homeland security]], [[military]] and [[weapon maker]]s, universities<ref>see e.g. http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/content/41/11_Part_1/4378.full-text.pdf</ref> and schools, research companies, hospitals, as well as [[energy companies]].
==Products== Products include:<ref>http://www.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/ucle</ref> *Radiation Air and Water Monitors *[[Aerial reconnaissance]] *[[alpha radiation|alpha]], beta, gamma and [[tritium monitor]]s *[[Unmanned aerial vehicle|Drone]]RAD aerial [[Radioactivity|radiation detection]]<ref>http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/southern-california-commercial-uav-company-teams-up-with-radiation-detection-company-otcbb-ucle-2159384.htm</ref><ref>http://tech-associates.com/product-info/DroneRad.pdf</ref> *Vehicle monitors, personnel monitors, exit monitors and room monitors<ref>https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/PortRadPortalMons-MSR_0315-508.pdf</ref> *[[Radon air monitor]]s and radon switch products *Handheld [[survey meter]]s and personal [[dosimeter]]s *Pocket micro-R meters *[[Port security]] equipment *software solutions
==Operating divisions== US Nuclear Corp has three divisions:<ref>http://new.usnuclearcorp.com/investor-relations/</ref> *Technical Associates, founded in 1946 as a spin off from the [[Manhattan Project]], built the first industrial grade radiation monitors.<ref>http://www.tech-associates.com/corporateprofile/corporateprofile.pdf</ref> *[[Overhoff Technology]] Corporation, design and manufacturing of high quality [[tritium]] monitors<ref>http://www.overhoff.com/</ref> *Electronic Control Concepts (ECC), [[X-ray]] equipment <ref>http://eccxray.com/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/us-nuclear-corp-ucle-makes-third-acquisition-as-part-aggressive-growth-through-acquisition-2156067.htm|date=2016-09-07|title=US Nuclear Corp. UCLE Makes Third Acquisition as Part of Aggressive Growth-Through-Acquisition Strategy }}</ref>
==See also== * [[radioactivity]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *http://www.usnuclearcorp.com/ *http://www.nasdaq.com/symbol/ucle *{{cite web | title=US Nuclear Corp. Announces 2016 Annual Financial Results | website=NASDAQ.com | date=2017-04-18 | url=http://www.nasdaq.com/press-release/us-nuclear-corp-announces-2016-annual-financial-results-20170418-00412 | ref={{sfnref | NASDAQ.com | 2017}} | access-date=2017-06-20}} [[Category:Nuclear industry]]

{{merge to|Strain rate tensor|discuss=Talk:Strain rate tensor#Proposed merge with Velocity gradient|date=October 2017}}
In [[fluid mechanics]] and [[continuum mechanics]], the '''velocity gradient''' describes how the [[velocity field|velocity]] of a fluid changes between different points within the fluid.<ref>{{cite book|title=A Dictionary of Chemical Engineering|author=Carl Schaschke|year=2014|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199651450}}</ref> Though the term can refer to the differences in velocity between layers of flow in a pipe,<ref>{{cite web| title =Infoplease: Viscosity: The Velocity Gradient|url = https://www.infoplease.com/encyclopedia/science-and-technology/physics/physics/viscosity/the-velocity-gradient}}</ref> it is often used to mean the [[Spatial gradient|gradient]] of a flow's velocity with respect to its [[coordinate system#Common coordinate systems|coordinates]].<ref name = "continuum">{{cite web|title = Velocity gradient at continuummechanics.org |url = http://continuummechanics.org/cm/velocitygradient.html}}</ref> The concept has implications in a variety of areas of [[physics]] and [[engineering]], including [[magnetohydrodynamics]], mining and water treatment.<ref name = "MHD"> {{citation | last = Zhang | first = Zujin | title = Generalized MHD System with Velocity Gradient in Besov Spaces of Negative Order | journal = Acta Applicandae Mathematicae | date = June 2017 | volume = 149 | number = 1 | pages = 139–144 | issn = 1572-9036 | doi = 10.1007/s10440-016-0091-0 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10440-016-0091-0 }}</ref><ref name = "Mines"> {{citation | title = Fundamental Flashback, Blowoff, and Yellow-Tip Limits of Fuel Gas-Air Mixtures | last = Grumer, J. | last2 = Harris, M. E. | last3 = Rowe, V. R. | department = Bureau of Mines | issue = RI 5225 | date = Jul 1956 | url = https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc38640/m2/1/high_res_d/metadc38640.pdf }}</ref><ref name = "Watertreatment"> {{citation | title = Influence of velocity gradient in a hydraulic flocculator on NOM removal by aerated spiral-wound ultrafiltration membranes (ASWUF) | first1 = J.C. | last1 = Rojas | first2 = B. | last2 = Moreno | first3 = G. | last3 = Garralón | first4 = F. | last4 = Plaza | first5 = J. | last5 = Pérez | first6 = M.A. | last6 = Gómez | journal = Journal of Hazardous Materials | volume = 178 | number = 1 | pages = 535–540 | year = 2010 | issn = 0304-3894 | doi = 10.1016/j.jhazmat.2010.01.116 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304389410001524 }}</ref>
==A simple example== Consider the velocity field of a fluid flowing through a [[pipe (fluid conveyance)|pipe]]. The layer of fluid in contact with the pipe tends to be at rest with respect to the pipe. This is called the [[no slip condition]].<ref>{{cite web| title = Review of fluid mechanics terminology|first1 = R.| last1 = Levicky| url = http://faculty.poly.edu/~rlevicky/Handout2_6333.pdf }}</ref> If the velocity difference between fluid layers at the centre of the pipe and at the sides of the pipe is sufficiently small, then the fluid flow is observed in the form of continuous layers. This type of flow is called [[laminar flow]].
The [[flow velocity]] difference between adjacent layers can be measured in terms of a velocity gradient, given by <math> \Delta u / \Delta y</math>. Where <math>\Delta u</math> is the difference in flow velocity between the two layers and <math>\Delta y</math> is the [[distance]] between the layers.
== Dimensional analysis == By performing [[dimensional analysis]], the dimensions of velocity gradient can be determined. The dimensions of velocity are <math> M^{0} L^{1} T^{-1} </math> , and the dimensions of distance are <math> M^{0} L^{1} T^{0}</math>. Since the velocity gradient can be expressed as <math>\frac{\Delta \text{velocity}}{\Delta \text{distance}}</math>. Therefore, the velocity gradient has the same dimensions as this ratio, i.e. <math> M^{0} L^{0} T^{-1} </math>.
==Velocity gradient in continuum mechanics== In 3 dimensions, the gradient, <math>\nabla\bf{v}</math> , of the velocity <math>\bf{v}</math> is a second-order [[tensor]] which can be expressed as the [[matrix (mathematics)|matrix]] L:
:<math>\bf{L} = \nabla\bf{v} = \begin{bmatrix} {\frac{\partial v_x}{\partial x}} & {\frac{\partial v_x}{\partial y}} & {\frac{\partial v_x}{\partial z}} \\ {\frac{\partial v_y}{\partial x}} & {\frac{\partial v_y}{\partial y}} & {\frac{\partial v_y}{\partial z}\ } \\ {\frac{\partial v_z}{\partial x}} & {\frac{\partial v_z}{\partial y}} & {\frac{\partial v_z}{\partial z}} \end{bmatrix}</math>
<math>\bf{L}</math> can be decomposed into the sum of a [[symmetric matrix]] <math>\textbf{E}</math> and a [[skew-symmetric matrix]] <math>\textbf{W}</math> as follows :<math>\begin{align} \bf{E} &= \frac{1}{2} \left(\bf{L} + \bf{L}^\textsf{T}\right) \\ \bf{W} &= \frac{1}{2} \left(\bf{L} - \bf{L}^\textsf{T}\right) \end{align}</math>
<math>\textbf{E}</math> is called the [[strain rate tensor]] and describes the rate of stretching and shearing. <math>\textbf{W}</math> is called the spin tensor and describes the rate of rotation.<ref name = "stuart">{{cite book| last = Gonzalez|first = O.|last2 = Stuart| first2 = A. M.| year = 2008| title = A First Course in Continuum Mechanics| series = Cambridge Texts in Applied Mathematics| publisher = Cambridge University Press| pages = 134-135}} </ref>
== Relationship between shear stress and the velocity field == [[Sir Isaac Newton]] proposed that [[shear stress]] is directly proportional to the velocity gradient: <ref>{{cite book|title = An Introduction to Fluid Dynamics|last = Batchelor| first = G.K.| isbn=9780521663960| series=Cambridge Mathematical Library| url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Rla7OihRvUgC| year=2000| publisher=Cambridge University Press| pages = 145}} </ref> : <math>\tau = \mu\frac{\partial u} {\partial y}</math>.
The [[constant of proportionality]], <math>\mu</math>, is called the [[Viscosity#Definition|dynamic viscosity]].
== Applications == The study of velocity gradients is useful in analysing path dependent materials and in the subsequent study of stresses and strains; e.g., [[Plastic deformation]] of [[metals]].<ref name = "continuum" /> The near-wall velocity gradient of the unburned reactants flowing from a tube is a key parameter for characterising flame stability.<ref name = "Mines" />{{rp|1-3}} The velocity gradient of a [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] can define conditions for the solutions to fundamental equations in magnetohydrodynamics.<ref name = "MHD"/>
== See also == * [[Finite strain theory#Time-derivative of the deformation gradient]], the spatial and material velocity gradient from continuum mechanics
== References == {{Reflist}}
<!--- Categories ---> [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Fluid mechanics]] [[Category:Continuum mechanics]]

CCPPLLJZDQAOHD-GJGKEFFFBZ | InChI3 = 1S/C18H32O3/c1-2-3-10-13-16-17(21-16)14-11-8-6-4-5-7-9-12-15-18(19)20/h8,11,16-17H,2-7,9-10,12-15H2,1H3,(H,19,20)/b11-8-/t16-,17+/m1/s1 | InChI3_Comment = (+)-isomer | InChIKey3 = CCPPLLJZDQAOHD-GJGKEFFFSA-N }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | C=18 | H=32 | O=3 | Appearance = Colorless oil | Density = | Solubility = Insoluble | Solvent = other solvents | SolubleOther = organic solvents | MeltingPtC = 23 to 25 | MeltingPt_notes = | BoilingPt = | pKa = | Viscosity = }} |Section3={{Chembox Structure | MolShape = | Dipole = }} |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | MainHazards = flammable | RPhrases = | SPhrases = }} |Section8={{Chembox Related | OtherFunction_label = compounds | OtherFunction = }} }}
'''Vernolic acid''' ('''leukotoxin''') is a [[long chain fatty acid]] that is [[monounsaturated]] and contains an [[epoxide]]. It is the ''cis'' epoxide derived from the C12–C13 alkene of [[linoleic acid]] and exists both the (+)- and (–)- [[optical isomers]].<ref>{{PubChem|6449780}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ebi.ac.uk/chebi/chebiOntology.do?chebiId=CHEBI:38300 | title = CHEBI:38300 - (−)-vernolic acid | work = Chemical Entities of Biological Interest (ChEBI) | publisher = European Bioinformatics Institute (EBI) }}</ref> It is an isomer of [[coronaric acid]], the two enantiomeric forms resulting instead by epoxidation at the C9–C10 alkene.<ref>{{PubChem|6246154}}</ref> Vernolic acid was first definitively characterized in 1954.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gunstone FD | year = 1954| title = Fatty acids. Part II. The nature of the oxygenated acid present in ''Vernonia anthelmintica'' (Willd.) seed oil | url = | journal = Journal of the Chemical Society | volume = 1954 | issue = | pages = 1611–1616 | doi = 10.1039/JR9540001611 }}</ref> It is the key component in vernonia oil, which is produced in abundance by the genera Vernonia and Euphorbia and is a potentially useful biofeedstock.
==Toxicity== In a variety of mammalian species, vernolic acid is made by the metabolism of [[linoleic acid]] by certain [[cytochrome P450]] [[epoxygenase]] enzymes; under these circumstances it is termed leukotoxin because of its toxic effects on [[leukocytes]] and other cell types and of its ability to produce multiple organ failure and respiratory distress when injected into rodent animal models of the [[acute respiratory distress syndrome]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Linhartová I, Bumba L, Mašín J, Basler M, Osička R, Kamanová J, Procházková K, Adkins I, Hejnová-Holubová J, Sadílková L, Morová J, Sebo P | title = RTX proteins: a highly diverse family secreted by a common mechanism | journal = FEMS Microbiology Reviews | volume = 34 | issue = 6 | pages = 1076–112 | date = November 2010 | pmid = 20528947 | pmc = 3034196 | doi = 10.1111/j.1574-6976.2010.00231.x }}</ref><ref name = "Spector_2015">{{cite journal | vauthors = Spector AA, Kim HY | title = Cytochrome P450 epoxygenase pathway of polyunsaturated fatty acid metabolism | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1851 | issue = 4 | pages = 356–65 | date = April 2015 | pmid = 25093613 | pmc = 4314516 | doi = 10.1016/j.bbalip.2014.07.020 }}</ref> These effects appear due to the conversion of vernolic acid to its dihydroxy counterparts, 12''S'',13''R''- and 12''R'',13''S''-dihydroxy-''cis''-9-octadecenoic acids by [[soluble epoxide hydrolase]] (this dihydroxy mixture has been termed leukotoxin diol).<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Greene JF, Newman JW, Williamson KC, Hammock BD | title = Toxicity of epoxy fatty acids and related compounds to cells expressing human soluble epoxide hydrolase | journal = Chemical Research in Toxicology | volume = 13 | issue = 4 | pages = 217–26 | date = April 2000 | pmid = 10775319 | doi = 10.1021/tx990162c }}</ref><ref name = "Spector_2015" /> Some studies suggest but have not yet proven that vernolic acid is responsible for or contributes to multiple organ failure, respiratory distress, and certain other cataclysmic diseases in humans (see [[epoxygenase]] subsection on linoleic acid).
==Vernonia oil== Vernonia oil is extracted from the seeds of the ''[[Vernonia galamensis]]'' (or ironweed), a plant native to eastern [[Africa]]. The seeds contain about 40 to 42% oil of which 73 to 80% is vernolic acid. The best varieties of ''V. anthelmintica'' contain about 30% less vernolic acid. Products that can be made from vernonia oil include epoxies for manufacturing [[adhesive]]s, [[varnish]]es and [[paint]]s, and industrial coatings. Its low [[viscosity]] recommends its use as a nonvolatile [[solvent]] in [[oil-based paint]]s since it will become incorporated in the dry paint rather than evaporating into the air.''<ref>{{cite book | url = http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/afcm/vernonia.html | title = Alternative Field Crops Manual | chapter = Vernonia | vauthors = Teynor TM, Putnam DJ, Oplinger ES, Oelke EA, Kelling KA, Doll JD | accessdate = 2006-09-10 | date = February 1992 }}</ref>
This use of vernonia oil offers potential [[Natural environment|environmental]] benefits, since its use could reduce emissions associated with man-made chemicals.
In its application as an [[epoxy]] oil,<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/proceedings1999/v4-272.html | vauthors = Mohamed AI, Mebrahtu T, Andebrhan T | year = 1999 | title = Variability in oil and vernolic acid contents in the new Vernonia galamensis collection from East Africa | pages = 272–274 | veditors = Janick J | journal = Perspectives on new crops and new uses | accessdate = 2006-09-10 }}</ref> vernonia oil competes with [[soybean oil|soybean]] or [[linseed oil]], which supply most of the market for these applications. Its low [[viscosity]] makes it more desirable than fully [[epoxidation|epoxidized]] linseed or soybean oils. It is more comparable to partially epoxidized linseed or soybean oil.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Muturi | first1 = Patrick | last2 = Wang | first2 = Danqing | last3 = Dirlikov | first3 = Stoil | name-list-format = vanc | title = Epoxidized vegetable oils as reactive diluents I. Comparison of vernonia, epoxidized soybean and epoxidized linseed oils | journal = Progress in Organic Coatings | volume = 25 | pages = 85–94 | year = 1994 | doi = 10.1016/0300-9440(94)00504-4 }}</ref>
==Other plant sources== Vernolic acid is not commonly found in plants in significant quantities, but some plants which do contain it are ''[[Vernonia]]'', ''[[Stokesia (plant)|Stokesia]]'', ''[[Crepis]]'' (from the [[Asteraceae|daisy family]]), and ''[[Euphorbia]] [[Euphorbia lagascae|lagascae]]'' and ''[[Bernardia]] [[Bernardia pulchella|pulchella]]'' from the [[Euphorbiaceae]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cahoon EB, Ripp KG, Hall SE, McGonigle B | title = Transgenic production of epoxy fatty acids by expression of a cytochrome P450 enzyme from Euphorbia lagascae seed | journal = Plant Physiology | volume = 128 | issue = 2 | pages = 615–24 | date = February 2002 | pmid = 11842164 | pmc = 148923 | doi = 10.1104/pp.010768 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|33em}}
[[Category:Vegetable oils]] [[Category:Fatty acids]] [[Category:Epoxides]] [[Category:Alkenoic acids]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2601:240:D602:F020:C9E0:9025:DAC7:71AD|2601:240:D602:F020:C9E0:9025:DAC7:71AD]] ([[User talk:2601:240:D602:F020:C9E0:9025:DAC7:71AD|talk]]) to last revision by Andy Dingley. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
'''Vitallium''' is a [[trademark]] for an [[alloy]] of 65% [[cobalt]], 30% [[chromium]], 5% [[molybdenum]], and other substances. The alloy is used in [[dentistry]] and [[artificial joint]]s, because of its resistance to [[corrosion]]. It is also used for components of [[turbocharger]]s because of its [[hot strength|thermal resistance]]. Vitallium was developed by Albert W. Merrick for the Austenal Laboratories in 1932. [[File:Subperiosteal maxillary implant.jpg|thumb|Subperiosteal maxillary implant made of vitallium 1977]]
In 2016 Norman Sharp, a 91 year old British man, was recognised as having the world's oldest [[hip replacement]] implants. The two vitallium implants were implanted in November 1948 at the [[Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital]], under the newly formed [[National Health Service|NHS]]. The 67 year old implants had such an unusually long life, partly because they had not required the typical replacement of such implants, but also because of Mr Sharp's young age of 23 when they were implanted, owing to a childhood case of [[septic arthritis]].<ref >{{Cite web |title=Former RNOH patient has world's oldest hip replacements |website=[[Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital]] |date=21 March 2016 |url=https://www.rnoh.nhs.uk/home/news/16/03/former-rnoh-patient-has-worlds-oldest-hip-replacements }}</ref>
For high-temperature use in engines, particularly turbochargers, the first alloy used was [[Haynes International|Haynes]] [[Stellite]] Nº 21, similar to Vitallium. This was suggested by the British engineer, and denture wearer, [[Samuel Dalziel Heron|S.D. Heron]] during WWII. Although the characteristics of the material obviously suggested itself for making turbocharger blades, it was thought impossible to cast it to the precision needed. Heron demonstrated that it could be, by showing his Vitallium dentures.<ref >{{Cite book |title=Power To Fly |chapter=Supercharging |first=L.J.K. |last=Setright |authorlink=L.J.K. Setright |publisher=George Allen & Unwin |isbn=0-04-338041-7 |page=195 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S1044-5803(01)00127-9 | title = Porosity structure and mechanical properties of vitalium-type alloy for implants | year = 2001 | author = Wojnar, L | journal = Materials Characterization | volume = 46 | pages = 221-225 | issue = 2–3}} *{{cite journal | doi = 10.1023/A:1018607219482 | title = Effect of silicon ion implantation on the properties of a cast Co–Cr–Mo alloy | year = 1997 | author = Kaminski, M | journal = Journal of Materials Science | volume = 32 | pages = 3727-3732 | last2 = Baszkiewicz | first2 = J | last3 = Kozubowski | first3 = J | last4 = Bednarska | first4 = A | last5 = Barcz | first5 = A | last6 = Gawlik | first6 = G | last7 = Jagielski | first7 = J | issue = 14| bibcode = 1997JMatS..32.3727K }}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060528151502/http://www.dentalarticles.com/products/20330.html Articles on Vitallium from DentalArticles.com] *[https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4306/ch3.htm NASA article mentioning Vitallium in turbochargers]
{{alloy-stub}} [[Category:Cobalt alloys]] [[Category:Chromium alloys]] [[Category:Biomaterials]] [[Category:Named alloys]]

[[File:Waist-hip ratio.svg|thumb|300px|Waist–hip ratio measurement]] '''The Waist-hip ratio''' or '''waist-to-hip ratio''' ('''WHR''') is the [[dimensionless]] [[ratio]] of the circumference of the [[waist]] to that of the [[hip]]s. This is calculated as waist measurement divided by hip measurement (<var>W</var> ÷ <var>H</var>). For example, a person with a 30″ ({{convert|30|in|cm|disp=out}}) waist and 38″ ({{convert|38|in|cm|disp=out}}) hips has a waist-hip ratio of about 0.78.
The WHR has been used as an indicator or measure of health, and the risk of developing serious health conditions. WHR correlates with fertility (with different optimal values in males and females).
== Measurement ==
=== WHO protocol === According to the [[World Health Organization]]'s data gathering protocol,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/chp/steps/en/ |title=STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) | publisher=World Health Organization |accessdate=March 21, 2012}}</ref> the waist circumference should be measured at the midpoint between the lower margin of the last palpable ribs and the top of the [[iliac crest]], using a stretch‐resistant tape that provides a constant 100 g tension. Hip circumference should be measured around the widest portion of the buttocks, with the tape parallel to the floor.<ref name=whoreport /> Other organizations use slightly different standards. The United States [[National Institutes of Health]] and the [[National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey]] used results obtained by measuring at the top of the iliac crest. Waist measurements are usually obtained by laypersons by measurings around the waist at the [[navel]], but research has shown that these measurements may underestimate the true waist circumference.<ref name=whoreport />
For both measurements, the individual should stand with feet close together, arms at the side and body weight evenly distributed, and should wear little clothing. The subject should be relaxed, and the measurements should be taken at the end of a normal respiration. Each measurement should be repeated twice; if the measurements are within 1 cm of one another, the average should be calculated. If the difference between the two measurements exceeds 1 cm, the two measurements should be repeated.<ref name=whoreport>{{cite web |url=http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2011/9789241501491_eng.pdf |title=Waist Circumference and Waist-Hip Ratio, Report of a WHO Expert Consultation |date=8–11 December 2008 | publisher=World Health Organization |accessdate=March 21, 2012}}</ref>
=== Practical measurement === Practically, however, the waist is more conveniently measured simply at the smallest circumference of the natural waist, usually just above the belly button, and the hip circumference may likewise be measured at its widest part of the buttocks or hip.<ref>In some places it is commonly accepted that a woman's waist is measured one inch (2.5cm) above her navel and that a man is measured one inch below his navel. [http://www.healthcalculators.org/calculators/waist_hip.asp Waist To Hip Calculator] at University of Maryland Medical System. Retrieved Dec 2010</ref> Also, in case the waist is convex rather than concave, such as is the case in pregnancy, different body types, and obesity, the waist may be measured at a horizontal level 1 inch above the navel.<ref name=Brown>{{cite journal |vauthors=Brown JE, Potter JD, Jacobs DR, Kopher RA, Rourke MJ, Barosso GM, Hannan PJ, Schmid LA | title = Maternal Waist-to-Hip Ratio as a Predictor of Newborn Size: Results of the Diana Project | journal = Epidemiology | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | pages = 62–6 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8664403 | doi = 10.1097/00001648-199601000-00011 | jstor = 3702758 }}</ref>
== Indicator of health == The WHR has been used as an indicator or measure of health, and the risk of developing serious health conditions. Research shows that people with "apple-shaped" bodies (with more weight around the waist) face more health risks than those with "pear-shaped" bodies who carry more weight around the hips.
WHR is used as a measurement of [[obesity]], which in turn is a possible indicator of other more serious health conditions. The [[World Health Organization|WHO]] states that [[abdominal obesity]] is defined as a waist-hip ratio above 0.90 for males and above 0.85 for females, or a [[body mass index]] (BMI) above 30.0.<ref name="WHO">http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2011/9789241501491_eng.pdf</ref> The National Institute of Diabetes, Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) states that women with waist-hip ratios of more than 0.8, and men with more than 1.0, are at increased health risk because of their fat distribution.<ref name="NIDDK">{{cite web|url=http://www.freedieting.com/tools/waist_to_hip_ratio.htm|title=Waist to Hip Ratio|work=freedieting.com}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- !rowspan=2| !colspan=2| DGSP<ref>[http://www.dgsp.de/_downloads/allgemein/S1_Leitlinie.pdf S 1- Leitlinie Vorsorgeuntersuchung im Sport. 2007] Dt. Gesellschaft für Sportmedizin und Prävention e.V. (DGSP)</ref> !colspan=2| WHO<ref name="WHO"/> !colspan=2| NIDDK<ref name="NIDDK"/> |- ! Women !! Men ! Women !! Men ! Women !! Men |- ! under-weight | {{dunno}} || {{dunno}} | {{dunno}} || {{dunno}} | {{dunno}} || {{dunno}} |- ! normal weight | < 0.80 || < 0.90 | {{dunno}} || {{dunno}} | {{dunno}} || {{dunno}} |- ! over-weight | 0.80–0.84 || 0.90–0.99 | {{dunno}} || {{dunno}} | {{dunno}} || {{dunno}} |- ! [[obesity]]<!--adipositas--> | > 0.85 || > 1.00 | > 0.85 || > 0.90 | > 0.80 || > 1.00 |}
WHR has been found to be a more efficient predictor of mortality in older people (>75 years of age) than waist circumference or BMI.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Price GM, Uauy R, Breeze E, Bulpitt CJ, Fletcher AE | title = Weight, shape, and mortality risk in older persons: elevated waist-hip ratio, not high body mass index, is associated with a greater risk of death | journal = Am. J. Clin. Nutr. | volume = 84 | issue = 2 | pages = 449–60 | date = August 2006 | pmid = 16895897 | laysummary = http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/medicalnews.php?newsid=49218 }}</ref> If obesity is redefined using WHR instead of BMI, the proportion of people categorized as at risk of heart attack worldwide increases threefold.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Yusuf S, Hawken S, Ounpuu S, Bautista L, Franzosi MG, Commerford P, Lang CC, Rumboldt Z, Onen CL, Lisheng L, Tanomsup S, Wangai P, Razak F, Sharma AM, Anand SS | title = Obesity and the risk of myocardial infarction in 27,000 participants from 52 countries: a case-control study | journal = Lancet | volume = 366 | issue = 9497 | pages = 1640–9 | date = November 2005 | pmid = 16271645 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67663-5 }}</ref> The [[body fat percentage]] is considered to be an even more accurate measure of relative weight. Of these three measurements, only the waist-hip ratio takes account of the differences in body structure. Hence, it is possible for two women to have vastly different body mass indices but the same waist–hip ratio, or to have the same body mass index but vastly different waist-hip ratios.
WHR has been shown to be a better predictor of cardiovascular disease than waist circumference and body-mass index.<ref name="MørkedalRomundstad2011">{{cite journal |vauthors=Mørkedal B, Romundstad PR, Vatten LJ | title = Informativeness of indices of blood pressure, obesity and serum lipids in relation to ischaemic heart disease mortality: the HUNT-II study | journal = European Journal of Epidemiology | volume = 26 | issue = 6 | pages = 457–461 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21461943 | pmc = 3115050 | doi = 10.1007/s10654-011-9572-7 | issn = 0393-2990 }}</ref> However, other studies have found waist circumference, not WHR, to be a good indicator of cardiovascular risk factors,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dobbelsteyn CJ, Joffres MR, MacLean DR, Flowerdew G | title = A comparative evaluation of waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio and body mass index as indicators of cardiovascular risk factors. The Canadian Heart Health Surveys | journal = Int. J. Obes. Relat. Metab. Disord. | volume = 25 | issue = 5 | pages = 652–61 | date = May 2001 | pmid = 11360147 | doi = 10.1038/sj.ijo.0801582 }}</ref> body fat distribution,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ketel IJ, Volman MN, Seidell JC, Stehouwer CD, Twisk JW, Lambalk CB | title = Superiority of skinfold measurements and waist over waist-to-hip ratio for determination of body fat distribution in a population-based cohort of Caucasian Dutch adults | journal = Eur. J. Endocrinol. | volume = 156 | issue = 6 | pages = 655–61 | date = June 2007 | pmid = 17535865 | doi = 10.1530/EJE-06-0730 }}</ref> and hypertension in type 2 diabetes.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Picon PX, Leitão CB, Gerchman F, Azevedo MJ, Silveiro SP, Gross JL, Canani LH | title = [Waist measure and waist-to-hip ratio and identification of clinical conditions of cardiovascular risk: multicentric study in type 2 diabetes mellitus patients] | language = Portuguese | journal = Arq Bras Endocrinol Metabol | volume = 51 | issue = 3 | pages = 443–9 | date = April 2007 | pmid = 17546244 }}</ref>
=== Stress === The anti-stress hormone [[cortisol]] is regulated by the [[HPA axis|hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis]] and has been associated with higher levels of abdominal fat and therefore a higher WHR.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wardle|first1=J|last2=Chida|first2=Y|last3=Gibson|first3=EL|last4=Whitaker|first4=KL|last5=Steptoe|first5=A|title=Stress and adiposity: a meta-analysis of longitudinal studies|journal=Obesity|date=2011|volume=19|issue=4|pages=771–778|doi=10.1038/oby.2010.241|pmid=20948519}}</ref> Abdominal fat is a marker of visceral fat (stored around important internal organs such as the liver, pancreas and intestines) and has greater blood flow and more receptors for cortisol than peripheral fat. The greater the number of cortisol receptors, the more sensitive the visceral fat tissue is to cortisol. This heightened sensitivity to cortisol stimulates fat cells to further increase in size.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pedersen|first1=SB|last2=Jonler|first2=M|last3=Richelsen|first3=B|title=Characterization of regional and gender differences in glucocorticoid receptors and lipoprotein lipase activity in human adipose tissue. Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|journal=Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|date=1994|volume=78|issue=1|pages=1354–1359}}</ref> Women who have a combination of normal [[Body mass index|BMI]] and high WHR experience elevated cortisol reactivity to acute stressors and failure to habituate to repeated stressors, compared to women with normal WHR.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Epel|first1=ES|last2=McEwen|first2=B|last3=Seeman|first3=T|last4=Matthews|first4=K|last5=Castellazzo|first5=G|last6=Brownell|first6=KD|title=Stress and body shape: stress-induced cortisol secretion is consistently greater among women with central fat|journal=Psychosomatic Medicine|date=2007|volume=62|issue=5|pages=623–632|pmid=11020091}}</ref> This suggests that high WHR might also indicate HPA-axis dysregulation and over-exposure to cortisol.
Evidence for the relationship between cortisol and central fat distribution has primarily been studied in individuals with [[Cushing’s syndrome]].<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Samaras|first1=K|last2=Campbell|first2=LV|title=The non-genetic determinants of central adiposity|journal=International Journal of Obesity and Related Metabolic Disorders : Journal of the International Association for the Study of Obesity|date=1997|volume=21|issue=10|pages=839–845|doi=10.1038/sj.ijo.0800502}}</ref> This is characterized by over-exposure to cortisol due to elevated activity of the [[HPA axis]]. A primary component of Cushing’s syndrome is the accumulation of fat in the abdominal region, and it is hypothesized that elevated cortisol levels contribute to this accumulation. However, this hypothesis remains contested as cortisol levels only modestly explain variation in central fat distribution. It is more likely that a complex set of biological and neuroendocrine pathways related to cortisol secretion contribute to central adiposity, such as [[leptin]], [[neuropeptide y]], [[corticotropin releasing factor]] and the sympathetic nervous system.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
== Growth and development == In general, adults with [[growth hormone]] deficiencies also have increased WHRs.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Murray|first1=R|title=Partial growth hormone deficiency is associated with an adverse cardiovascular risk profile and increased carotid intima-medial thickness|journal=Clinical Endocrinology (Oxford)|date=2010|volume=73|issue=4|pages=508–515}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal|last1=Gomes-Santos|first1=E|title=Increased visceral adiposity and cortisol to cortisone ratio in adults with congenital isolated GH deficiency.|journal=Journal of Clinical Endocrinology|date=2014|volume=99|issue=9|pages=3285–3289|doi=10.1210/jc.2014-2132}}</ref> Adults with untreated congenital isolated growth hormone deficiency have increased WHRs, possibly from increased cortisone:cortisol ratios and [[insulin]] sensitivities.<ref name="ReferenceB" /> Since these individuals have increased visceral obesity, it has been suggested that a minimal growth hormone secretion would theoretically increase insulin resistance.<ref name="ReferenceB" /> However, because of the growth hormone deficiency, this insulin resistance point cannot be reached and these individuals are more sensitive to insulin. Increased adipose deposits are therefore more likely to form in these individuals, causing the high WHR. Growth hormone deficiencies have also been correlated with WHRs in prepubertal children; the specific baseline body statistics, such as WHRs, of pre-pubertal children with growth hormone deficiencies can predict growth response effectiveness to artificial growth hormone therapies, such as rhGH treatments.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Esen|first1=I|title=The association between growth response to growth hormone and baseline body composition of children with growth hormone deficiency|journal=Growth Hormone and IGF Research|date=2013|volume=23|issue=5|pages=196–199|pmid=23890535|doi=10.1016/j.ghir.2013.07.001}}</ref>
=== Sex characteristics === Males with [[congenital adrenal hyperplasia]], determined by [[CYP21A2]] mutations, have increased WHRs.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Falhammer|first1=H|title=Cardiovascular risk, metabolic profile, and body composition in adult males with congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency|journal=European Journal of Endocrinology|date=2011|volume=164|issue=2|pages=285–293|pmid=21098686|doi=10.1530/EJE-10-0877}}</ref>
=== Fertility === A WHR of 0.9 for men and 0.7 for women has been shown to correlate strongly with general [[health]] and [[fertility]]. Women within the 0.7 range have optimal levels of [[estrogen]] and are less susceptible to major diseases such as [[diabetes]], cardiovascular disorders and ovarian cancers.<ref name="LiveScience">{{cite journal| title=The Rules of Attraction in the Game of Love| veditors=| publisher=| place=| pages=| url=http://www.livescience.com/health/060213_attraction_rules.html}}</ref> Women with high WHR (0.80 or higher) have significantly lower pregnancy rates than women with lower WHRs (0.70–0.79), independent of their BMIs.<ref name="Ratio">{{cite journal | author = Singh D | title = Female mate value at a glance: relationship of waist-to-hip ratio to health, fecundity and attractiveness | journal = Neuro Endocrinol. Lett. | volume = Suppl 4 | issue = | pages = 81–91 | date = December 2002 | pmid = 12496738 | url = http://faculty.bennington.edu/~sherman/sex/whr-singh2002.pdf | series = 23 }}</ref> Men with WHRs around 0.9, similarly, have been shown to be more healthy and fertile with less [[prostate cancer]] and [[testicular cancer]].<ref name="MarloweApicellaReed2005" />
Evidence suggests that WHR is an accurate somatic indicator of reproductive endocrinological status and long-term health risk. Among girls with identical body weights, those with lower WHRs show earlier pubertal endocrine activity, as measured by high levels of lutenizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone, as well as sex steroid (estradiol) activity. A Dutch prospective study on outcome in an artificial insemination program provides evidence for the role of WHR and fecundity.<ref name="zaadstra1993">{{cite journal |vauthors=Zaadstra BM, Seidell JC, Van Noord PA, te Velde ER, Habbema JD, Vrieswijk B, Karbaat J | title = Fat and female fecundity: prospective study of effect of body fat distribution on conception rates | journal = BMJ | volume = 306 | issue = 6876 | pages = 484–487 | year=1993 | pmid = 8448457 | pmc = 1676805 | doi=10.1136/bmj.306.6876.484}}</ref> These investigators report that a 0.1 unit increase in WHR decreases the probability of conception per cycle by 30% after adjustment for age, obesity, reasons for artificial insemination, cycle length and regularity, smoking, and parity.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Singh | year = 1993a | title = Adaptive significance of female physical attractiveness: Role of the waist-to-hip ratio | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 65 | issue = 2| pages = 293–307 | doi=10.1037/0022-3514.65.2.293 | pmid=8366421}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Singh | year = 1993b | title = Body shape and women's attractiveness. The critical role of waist-to-hip ratio | url = | journal = Human Nature | volume = 4 | issue = 3| pages = 297–321 | doi=10.1007/bf02692203| pmid = 24214368 }}</ref>
[[Menopause]], the natural or surgical cessation of the menstrual cycle, is due to an overall decrease in ovarian production of the hormones estradiol and progesterone. These hormonal changes are also associated with an increase in WHR independent of increases in body mass.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cagnacci|first1=A|last2=Zanin|first2=R|last3=Cannoletta|first3=M|last4=Generali|first4=M|last5=Caretto|first5=S|last6=Volpe|first6=A|title=Menopause, estrogens, progestins, or their combination on body weight and anthropometric measure|journal=Fertility and Sterility|date=2007|volume=88|issue=6|pages=1603–1608|doi=10.1016/j.fertnstert.2007.01.039|pmid=17481628}}</ref> Significantly, studies find that large premenopausal WHRs are associated with lower [[estradiol]] levels and variation in age of menopause onset.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Freeman|first1=EW|last2=Sammel|first2=MD|last3=Lin|first3=H|last4=Gracia|first4=CR|title=Obesity and reproductive hormone levels in the transition to menopause|journal=Menopause|date=2007|volume=17|issue=4|pages=718–726|pmid=20216473|doi=10.1097/gme.0b013e3181cec85d|pmc=2888623}}</ref> Circulating estrogen preferentially stores lipid deposits in the gluteofemoral region, including the buttocks and thighs, and evidence suggests that menopause-associated estrogen deficiency results in an accumulation of adipose deposits around the abdomen.<ref>Cagnacci et al., 2007</ref> These menopause-induced changes in body fat distribution can be counteracted with [[hormone replacement therapy]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Genazzani|first1=AR|last2=Gambacciani|first2=M|title=Effect of climacteric transition and hormone replacement therapy on body weight and body fat distribution|journal=Gynecological Endocrinology|date=2006|volume=22|issue=3|pages=145–150|doi=10.1080/09513590600629092|pmid=16835076}}</ref> In contrast, aging males gradually accumulate abdominal fat, and hence increased WHR, in parallel with declining [[androgen]] levels.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Samaras|first1=K|last2=Campbell|first2=LV|title=The non-genetic determinants of central adiposity|journal=International Journal of Obesity and Related Metabolic Disorders: Journal of the International Association for the study of Obesity|date=1997|volume=21|issue=10|pages=839–845|doi=10.1038/sj.ijo.0800502}}</ref>
=== Cognitive ability === Using data from the U.S. National Center for Health Statistics, William Lassek at the University of Pittsburgh in Pennsylvania and Steven Gaulin of the University of California, Santa Barbara, found a child's performance in cognitive tests correlated to their mother's waist–hip ratio, a proxy for how much fat she stores on her hips.<ref name=Lassek>{{cite journal|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=January 2008|title=Waist-hip ratio and cognitive ability: is gluteofemoral fat a privileged store of neurodevelopmental resources?|last=Lassek|first=W.|author2=Gaulin S. |doi=10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2007.07.005 |volume=29 |issue=1 |pages=26–34}}</ref>
Children whose mothers had wide hips and a low waist–hip ratio scored highest, leading Lassek and Gaulin to suggest that fetuses benefit from hip fat, which contains long chain [[polyunsaturated fat|polyunsaturated fatty acids]], critical for the development of the fetus's brain.<ref name=Lassek /> In addition, evidence suggests that children of low-WHR teens were protected from the cognitive deficits often associated with teen birth.
== Human genetics ==
Studies in twins have suggested that between 22% and 61% of variability in waist-to-hip ratio may be accounted for by genetic factors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhs.uk/news/2010/10October/Pages/pear-shaped-genes-found.aspx|title='Pear shaped' genes found – NHS Choices – Health News|work=www.nhs.uk}}</ref>
== Measure of female attractiveness == The concept and significance of WHR as an indicator of attractiveness was first theorized by [[evolutionary psychology|evolutionary psychologist]] [[Devendra Singh]] at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] in 1993.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Singh D | title = Adaptive significance of female physical attractiveness: role of waist-to-hip ratio | journal = J Pers Soc Psychol | volume = 65 | issue = 2 | pages = 293–307 | date = August 1993 | pmid = 8366421 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.65.2.293 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Buss |first=David |title=The Evolution of Desire: Strategies of Human Mating |url=http://www.human-nature.com/nibbs/04/buss.html |format=hardcover |edition=second|publisher=Basic Books |location=New York |chapter= |page=56}}</ref> Singh argued that the WHR was a more consistent estrogen marker than the [[BWH|bust–waist ratio]] (BWR) studied at [[King's College, London]] by Dr. [[Glenn Wilson (psychologist)|Glenn Wilson]] in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=30–4 |doi=10.2224/sbp.1974.2.1.30 |title=Psychological correlates of sexual attractiveness: An empirical demonstration of denial and fantasy gratification phenomena? |year=1974 |last1=Wilson |first1=Glenn D. |last2=Brazendale |first2=Anthony H. |journal=Social Behavior and Personality: an international journal |volume=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pages=201–5 |doi=10.1080/00224545.1975.9918705 |title=Vital Statistics, Perceived Sexual Attractiveness, and Response to Risque Humor |year=1975 |last1=Wilson |first1=Glenn |last2=Nias |first2=David |last3=Brazendale |first3=Anthony |journal=The Journal of Social Psychology |volume=95 |issue=2}}</ref>
Some researchers have found that the waist–hip ratio is a significant measure of [[Physical attractiveness#Determinants of female physical attractiveness|female attractiveness]].<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/relationships/man-woman/Perfect-waist-to-hip-ratio-is-07/articleshow/6438017.cms Perfect waist-to-hip ratio is 0.7]</ref> Women with a 0.7 WHR are usually rated as more attractive by men from [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] cultures.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Ethology and Sociobiology|last=Singh|first=Devendra|author2=Young, Robert K. |date=2001-06-27|title=Body Weight, Waist-to-Hip Ratio, Breasts, and Hips: Role in Judgments of Female Attractiveness and Desirability for Relationships|volume=16|issue=6|pages=483–507|url=http://web.missouri.edu/~rouderj/3010/readings/Singh.pdf|doi=10.1016/0162-3095(95)00074-7|format=PDF}}</ref> Preferences may vary, according to some studies,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fisher ML, Voracek M | title = The shape of beauty: determinants of female physical attractiveness | journal = J Cosmet Dermatol | volume = 5 | issue = 2 | pages = 190–4 | date = June 2006 | pmid = 17173598 | doi = 10.1111/j.1473-2165.2006.00249.x }}</ref> ranging from 0.6 in China, South America, and some of Africa<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dixson BJ, Dixson AF, Li B, Anderson MJ | title = Studies of human physique and sexual attractiveness: sexual preferences of men and women in China | journal = Am J Hum Biol | volume = 19 | issue = 1 | pages = 88–95 | date = January 2007 | pmid = 17160976 | doi = 10.1002/ajhb.20584 }}</ref> to 0.8 in Cameroon and among the Hadza tribe of Tanzania,<ref name="MarloweApicellaReed2005">{{cite journal |pages=458–68 |url=http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~hbe-lab/acrobatfiles/profilewhr.pdf |doi=10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2005.07.005 |title=Men's preferences for women's profile waist-to-hip ratio in two societies |year=2005 |last1=Marlowe |first1=F |last2=Apicella |first2=C |last3=Reed |first3=D |journal=Evolution and Human Behavior |volume=26 |issue=6}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Personality and Individual Differences| last=Marlowe|first= F.|author2=Wetsman, A. |year=2001|title=Preferred waist-to-hip ratio and ecology|volume=30|issue=3|pages=481–489|url=http://www.fas.harvard.edu/%7Ehbe-lab/acrobatfiles/preferred%20waist.pdf|doi=10.1016/S0191-8869(00)00039-8|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Dixson BJ, Dixson AF, Morgan B, Anderson MJ | title = Human physique and sexual attractiveness: sexual preferences of men and women in Bakossiland, Cameroon | journal = Arch Sex Behav | volume = 36 | issue = 3 | pages = 369–75 | date = June 2007 | pmid = 17136587 | doi = 10.1007/s10508-006-9093-8 }}</ref> with divergent preferences according to the ethnicity of the observed being noted.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Freedman RE, Carter MM, Sbrocco T, Gray JJ | title = Do men hold African-American and Caucasian women to different standards of beauty? | journal = Eat Behav | volume = 8 | issue = 3 | pages = 319–33 | date = August 2007 | pmid = 17606230 | pmc = 3033406 | doi = 10.1016/j.eatbeh.2006.11.008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Freedman RE, Carter MM, Sbrocco T, Gray JJ | title = Ethnic differences in preferences for female weight and waist-to-hip ratio: a comparison of African-American and White American college and community samples | journal = Eat Behav. | volume = 5 | issue = 3 | pages = 191–8 | date = July 2004 | pmid = 15135331 | doi = 10.1016/j.eatbeh.2004.01.002 }}</ref>
It appears that men in westernized societies are more influenced by female [[waist]] size than [[hip]] size:
{{quote|"Hip size indicates pelvic size and the amount of additional fat storage that can be used as a source of energy. Waist size conveys information such as current reproductive status or health status ... in westernized societies with no risk of seasonal lack of food, the waist, conveying information about [[fecundity]] and health status, will be more important than hip size for assessing a female's attractiveness."|''Journal of Biological Psychology''|<ref name="Rozmus-Wrzesinska ">{{cite journal |vauthors=Rozmus-Wrzesinska M, Pawlowski B |title=Men's ratings of female attractiveness are influenced more by changes in female waist size compared with changes in hip size |journal=Biol Psychol |volume=68 |issue=3 |pages=299–308 |date=March 2005 |pmid=15620796 |doi=10.1016/j.biopsycho.2004.04.007}}</ref>}}
By western standards, women in foraging populations have high numbers of pregnancies, high parasite loads, and high caloric dependence on fibrous foods. These variables change across cultures, suggesting that # the normal range of female WHR was often higher than in western cultures, # what constituted locally “WHR” varied, and # average WHR of [[nubile]] females and of females of peak fertility varied. Thus, a WHR that indicates pubertal onset, sex, fertility, hormonal irregularities, and/or differentiates male from female in one population may not do so in another.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=esDW3xTKoLIC|title=The Handbook of Evolutionary Psychology|last=Buss|first=David M.|date=2005-07-15|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9780471727224|language=en}}</ref>
In a series of 1993 studies done by Singh, men used WHR and overall body fat to determine a woman’s attractiveness. In his first study, men were shown a series of 12 drawings of women with various WHRs and body fat. Drawings with normal weight and a low WHR were associated with the most positive traits (i.e. attractive, sexy, intelligent and healthy). The drawings of thin female figures were not associated with any positive traits except youthfulness.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Singh|first=Devendra|date=1994-01-01|title=Is thin really beautiful and good? Relationship between waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) and female attractiveness|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0191886994901163|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=16|issue=1|pages=123–132|doi=10.1016/0191-8869(94)90116-3}}</ref>
Through this study, Singh suggests that males and females may have developed innate mechanisms which detect and make use of the WHR to assess how healthy an individual is and (particularly for men), infer possible mate value. Having a healthy mate improves the chances of producing offspring with inherited genetic protection from various diseases and a healthy mate is more likely to be a good parent (Hamilton & Zuk, 1982; Thornhill, 1993).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Singh|first=Devendra|last2=Young|first2=Robert K.|date=1995-11-01|title=Body weight, waist-to-hip ratio, breasts, and hips: Role in judgments of female attractiveness and desirability for relationships|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0162309595000747|journal=Ethology and Sociobiology|volume=16|issue=6|pages=483–507|doi=10.1016/0162-3095(95)00074-7}}</ref>
Other studies discovered WHR as a signal of attractiveness as well, beyond just examining body fat and fertility. Barnaby Dixson, Gina Grimshaw, Wayne Linklater, and Alan Dixson conducted a study using eye-tracking techniques to evaluate men's fixation on digitally altered photographs of the same woman, as well as asking the men to evaluate the images based on attractiveness. What they found was while men fixated on the woman's breasts in each photo, they selected the images where the woman had a 0.7 WHR as most attractive, regardless of breast size.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dixson|first=Barnaby J.|last2=Grimshaw|first2=Gina M.|last3=Linklater|first3=Wayne L.|last4=Dixson|first4=Alan F.|date=2011-02-01|title=Eye-tracking of men's preferences for waist-to-hip ratio and breast size of women|journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior|volume=40|issue=1|pages=43–50|doi=10.1007/s10508-009-9523-5|issn=1573-2800|pmid=19688590}}</ref>
Furthermore, referencing a 2005 study conducted by Johnson and Tassinary looking at animated human walking stimuli, Farid Pazhoohi and James R. Liddle proposed that men do not solely use WHR to evaluate attractiveness, but also a means of sex-differentiation, with higher WHR perceived as more masculine and lower WHR as an indicator of femininity. Pazhoohi and Liddle used this idea as a possible additional explanation as to why men perceive a lower WHR as more attractive – because it relates to an expression of femininity, as opposed to masculinity and a higher WHR.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Pazhoohi F., Liddle J. R. | year = 2012 | title = IDENTIFYING FEMININE AND MASCULINE RANGES FOR WAIST-TO-HIP RATIO | url = | journal = Journal of Social, Evolutionary & Cultural Psychology | volume = 6 | issue = 2| pages = 227–232 | doi=10.1037/h0099212}}</ref> On this basis, it was shown that men with lower, more feminine, WHRs feel less comfortable and self-report lower body esteem and self-efficacy than men with higher, more masculine, WHRs.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Pazhoohi F., Hosseinchari M., Doyle J. F. | year = 2012 | title = Iranian men's waist-to-hip ratios, shoulder-to-hip ratios, body esteem and self-efficacy | url = | journal = Journal of Evolutionary Psychology | volume = 10 | issue = 2| pages = 61–67 | doi=10.1556/jep.10.2012.2.2}}</ref>
To enhance their perceived attractiveness, some women may artificially alter their apparent WHR. The methods include the use of a [[corset]] to reduce the waist size and [[hip and buttock padding]] to increase the apparent size of the hips and buttocks. In an earlier attempt to quantify attractiveness, [[corset]] and [[girdle]] manufacturers of the 20th century used a calculation called ''hip spring''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corsetiere.net/Spirella/Corsetiere/Older.htm#hipspring|title=Bald|work=corsetiere.net}}</ref> (or ''hip-spring'' or ''hipspring''), calculated by subtracting the waist measurement from the hip measurement. However this calculation fell into disuse because it is a poor indicator of attractiveness; for example, a hip spring of {{convert|10|in}} would likely be considered quite attractive for an average-sized adult woman, but a child or petite woman with the same number would more likely be seen as malnourished.
WHR versus BMI attractiveness is related to fertility, not fat content. A study performed by Holliday used computer generated female body shapes to construct images which covary with real female body mass (indexed with BMI) and not with body shape (indexed with WHR), and vice versa. Twelve observers (6 male and 6 female) rated these images for attractiveness during an fMRI study. The attractiveness ratings were correlated with changes in BMI and not WHR. The results demonstrated that in addition to activation in higher visual areas, changes to BMI had a direct impact on activity within the brain’s reward system. This shows that BMI, not WHR, modulates reward mechanisms in the brain and that this may have important implications for judgements of ideal body size in eating disordered individuals.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Holliday I. E. |author2=Longe O. A. |author3=Thai N. |author4=Hancock P. B. |author5=Tovée M. J. | year = 2011 | title = BMI not WHR modulates BOLD fMRI responses in a sub-cortical reward network when participants judge the attractiveness of human female bodies | url = | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 6 | issue = 11| page = 11 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0027255 }}</ref>
Another study, conducted by Furnham, was used as an extension of Singh & Young's 1995 investigation. A total of 137 participants were in the study. There were 98 female participants. The age range was between 16 and 67. The majority of participants were undergraduates, and 90% were white British, the remainder being Asian (East Indian) and African. Their educational and socio-economic backgrounds (nearly all middle class) were fairly homogenous, and none had previously participated in any studies involving female body shape or attractiveness. It was predicted that the effect of breast size on judgment of attractiveness and age estimation would be dependent on overall body fat and the size of the waist-to-hip ratio.<ref name="Furnham">Furnham, Adrian, Melanie Dias, and Alastair McClelland. "The Role of Body Weight, Waist-to-Hip Ratio, and Breast Size in Judgments of Female Attractiveness – Springer." Sex Roles 39.3-4 (n.d.): 311-26.</ref>
All the participants were given a booklet with eight pictures in total. Each figure was identified as heavy or slender, feminine WHR or masculine WHR, and large-breasted or small-breasted. The participants rated the figures for four personal attributes (attractiveness, healthiness, femininity, and kindness/understanding).<ref name="Furnham" />
When ratings of the figures' attractiveness were made, generally it appeared that bust size, WHR, and their weight were all important contributory elements. The female participants rated the figures with a low WHR as more attractive, healthy, feminine looking, and in the case of the heavy figure, more kind/understanding than did male participants. This is a particularly interesting finding, as most previous studies report that young women idealize female bodies solely on the basis of thinness. As far as the breast sizes of the slender figures is concerned, whether they had large or small breasts did not appear to have any effect on the ratings of attractiveness or kindness/understanding, and having larger breasts only increased the mean ratings of health and femininity very slightly. However, a heavy figure with a high WHR and a large bust was rated as the least attractive and healthy by all participants.<ref name="Furnham" />
Waist-hip ratio is also a reliable cue to one’s sex and it is hypothesised that the "individuals who represent a mismatch based on the cue provided by WHR (e.g., women with high WHRs or men with low WHRs) would likely be viewed as unattractive by the opposite sex."<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Pazhoohi F, Liddle JR|title=Identifying feminine and masculine ranges for Waist-to-Hip ratio |journal=Journal of Social, Evolutionary, and Cultural Psychology |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=227–232 |date=June 2012 |doi=10.1037/h0099212}}</ref>
== Food == A number of studies have been carried out with focus on food composition of diets in relation to changes in waist circumference adjusted for body mass index.
Whole-grain, ready-to-eat, oat cereal diets reduce [[low-density lipoprotein cholesterol]] and waist circumference in overweight or obese adults more than low-fibre control food diets. Weight loss did not vary between groups.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Maki KC, Beiseigel JM, Jonnalagadda SS, Gugger CK, Reeves MS, Farmer MV, Kaden VN, Rains TM | title = Whole-grain ready-to-eat oat cereal, as part of a dietary program for weight loss, reduces low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in adults with overweight and obesity more than a dietary program including low-fiber control foods | journal = Journal of the American Dietetic Association | volume = 110 | issue = 2 | pages = 205–14 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20102847 | doi = 10.1016/j.jada.2009.10.037 }}</ref>
The mean annual change in waist circumference was more than 3 times as great for subjects in the white-bread cluster as subjects using a diet high in fruit, vegetables, reduced-fat dairy, and whole grains and low in red and processed meat, fast food, and soda.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Newby PK, Muller D, Hallfrisch J, Qiao N, Andres R, Tucker KL | title = Dietary patterns and changes in body mass index and waist circumference in adults | journal = The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition | volume = 77 | issue = 6 | pages = 1417–25 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12791618 }}</ref>
A 2011 study suggests that dietary pattern high in fruit and dairy and low in white bread, processed meat, margarine, and soft drinks may help to prevent abdominal fat accumulation.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Romaguera D, Ängquist L, Du H, Jakobsen MU, Forouhi NG, Halkjær J, Feskens EJ, van der A DL, Masala G, Steffen A, Palli D, Wareham NJ, Overvad K, Tjønneland A, Boeing H, Riboli E, Sørensen TI | title = Food composition of the diet in relation to changes in waist circumference adjusted for body mass index | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 6 | issue = 8 | pages = e23384 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21858094 | pmc = 3157378 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0023384 }}</ref>
